In a segment that ran on ZOOM (Boston, Mass. 02134) in the '70s, a Canadian kid hollowed out tight foot-wells in fairly large blocks of Styrofoam.  On the bottom of each block, he duck (yes, it really IS duck) taped trimmed-to-width slats of venetian blind along the "front" edge only.  He inserted Number 2 pencils perpendicularly at either end of the slats' taped edge to act as stops.  From a dock, he tucked his feet firmly into the blocks and slipped his way across a pond easy as you please.  When he moved one foot forward, the slats would flatten; when he pulled back the slats would resist against the water and pull towards the front, hitting the pencil-stops and allowing propulsion.

You would need a deep keel fin on each shoe to slow the sideways drift and tip over of each shoe. For forward propulsion some cross fins that fold out when you try to push back on the shoe and tuck in again when the shoe is shuffled forwards. The only dangers then are having the shoes shoot forwards out from under you. The other is that they could shoot forwards diagonally. Perhaps with the right angle of the keels though you could "speed skate" on water. The limiting straps to prevent you doing the splits would be a good idea, but having a keel as deep as possible and preferrably weighted to keep the shoe upright and not sliding sideways is priority.

I'm thinking the best idea would be something like a vague cone or pyramid pointed downward. You get as much of the styrofoam as possible underneath the surface of the water, so it's more stable, like an iceberg. You also want your feet buried deep into the foam (not on top of it) so your center of gravity is lower. Having your feet partially underwater will also give you more of an ability to push against the water and actually move forward, rather than just sloshing around on top. Basically, what you want to end up with is two cylinders a foot tall that are fully inside the water, attached on the top edge to a block of foam that floats on top of the water. When you put your feet inside the cylinders, you'll be nearly knee-deep in the water, but won't sink fully because of the buoyancy of the block of foam.

As a kid 40 years ago I had a pair of water shoes that worked just fine we got them at duanes toyland for the pool. They were Styrofoam thicker in the front with a lip about 15 inches back an inch or two high on the bottom thinning towards the back as you stepped it pushed water backwards sending you forwards. I actually walked to lake George village From our camp on the other side of the lake followed the shore line past million dollar beach just in case. Parents were not happy with that little adventure. waves were a little tricky I just thought it was fun.
